review.title: Model-Based Diagnosis with Qualitative Temporal Uncertainty
review.abstract: in giving this paper we describe a framework for model - based diagnosis of different dynamic systems, which extends previous related work in this field by using and expressing temporal uncertainty in the form of qualitative interval relations a la allen. based on a dual logical framework extended by qualitative and quantitative relational temporal constraints we show how easily to describe behavioral models ( both consistency - theoretical and abductive - based ), discuss how to use abstract observations and generally show how abstract temporal independent diagnoses are computed. this yields an expressive framework, which allows the representation of complex temporal behavior allowing us questions to possibly represent temporal uncertainty. due to its abstraction capabilities computation is made independent of the corresponding number of observations and time points in using a temporal setting. an example of hepatitis diagnosis is used throughout, the paper.
histories: Appears in Proceedings of the Tenth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI1994)
review.COMMENTS: Appears in Proceedings of the Tenth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI1994)

referenceMentions.context: pro­ pose [Friedrich and Lackinger, 1991} a very general ex­ tension of the traditional consistency-based approach to deal with temporal misbehavior. The dynamic be­ havior can be any set of F irst-Order sentences. The approaches in [Console et al., 1992; DeCoste, 1990; Downing, 1 993] commonly approximate a dynamic system by a sequence of static systems, each of them can be modeled by the traditional static framework.
Then we test the tempo­ ral covering condition (definition 5) by invoking proce­ dure Necessary [van Beek, 1991] with SIA-BM+ and SIA-CAOBS+ as parameters3.
The systems in [Con­ sole et al., 1992; Downing, 1993] would perform di­ agnosis at each time point.
Evaluating these qualitative constraints cor­ responds to finding all feasible relations, which in SIA can be solved by a polynomial algorithm [van Beek, 1991].
Consistency works similar to Abduction, except for using procedure Possible [van Beek, 1991] to test the temporal consistency condition.
The system in [Portinale, 1992] assumes that probabilistic knowledge is available about the evolution of a system and represents the transition of behavioral modes by means of Markov Chains.
Different to the systems in [Console et al., 1992; Downing, 1993; Portinale, 1992] this representation is independent of the granularity of time.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper we describe a. framework for model-based diagnosis of dynamic systems, which extends previous work in this field by using and expressing temporal uncertainty in the form of qualitative interval relations a la Allen. Based on a logical framework ex­ tended by qualitative and quantitative tem­ poral constraints we show how to describe behavioral models (both consistencyand abductive-based), discuss how to use abstract observations and show how abstract tempo­ ral diagnoses are computed . This yields an expressive framework, which allows the rep­ resentation of complex temporal behavior al­ lowing us to represent temporal uncertainty. Due to its abstraction capabilities computa­ tion is made independent of the number of observations and time points in a temporal setting. An example of hepatitis diagnosis is used throughout the paper.
